diy_objections.objection: Can't I just fix this myself? / I saw YouTube videos about this
diy_objections.ineffective_response: You'll make it worse / This requires professionals
diy_objections.authentic_response: I appreciate you being hands-on with your home - that's actually a good instinct for a lot of repairs. Foundation work is different because if it's not done right, you can actually make the structure less stable, and you'll have no warranty or recourse. Plus, most foundation solutions require equipment you can't rent - we're talking hydraulic piers, concrete pumps, and engineering calculations for load-bearing. What you CAN do yourself is improve drainage and downspouts, which helps prevent future issues. But for structural repairs, this is one where DIY creates more risk than savings. Would it help to see what's actually involved in the repair process?
diy_objections.psychology: Validates their capability, explains technical reality without condescension, offers alternative DIY contribution

→ Soil analysis
→ Moisture mapping
→ Load calculations

→ The company folds in 5 years

Foundation crack myth: "All cracks are bad."

Reality: 80% of foundation cracks are cosmetic.

Here's how to tell the difference 🧵

1/ HAIRLINE VERTICAL CRACKS
• <1/16" wide
• Straight up and down
• Concrete shrinkage (normal)
• Monitor but don't panic

Action: Take a photo, check in 6 months

2/ HORIZONTAL CRACKS
• Any width
• Running sideways
• Indicates pressure/load issues
• NEEDS IMMEDIATE INSPECTION

Action: Call a structural engineer TODAY

3/ STAIR-STEP CRACKS (block/brick)
• Follows mortar joints
• Diagonal pattern
• Settlement or soil movement
• Requires professional assessment

Action: Get 2-3 opinions from licensed contractors

4/ WIDE VERTICAL CRACKS (>1/4")
• Can indicate settlement
• Especially if doors stick
• May need stabilization

Action: Foundation inspection + soil test

5/ WHEN TO WORRY:
✗ Crack is growing
✗ Doors/windows won't close
✗ Floors are sloping
✗ Gaps at ceiling/wall joints
✗ Multiple crack types

Mark crack ends with pencil
Date it
Photo with ruler for scale
Check every 3 months

Growing = action needed

❌ Assume "old house" means "normal"

thread_structure: Unpopular opinion: Pier and beam foundations are superior to slab-on-grade for 80% of residential builds. Fight me. 🧵
Yes, slabs are cheaper upfront. $4-7/sq ft vs $8-12/sq ft. But let's talk total cost of ownership over 30 years.
Plumbing issue in a slab? Jackhammer time. $3K-15K depending on location. Pier and beam? Crawl under. $500-2K. I've seen this play out 100+ times.
Expansive clay soil (hello Texas, Oklahoma, Colorado)? Slab foundations move. Crack. Require expensive repairs. Pier and beam flexes.
Access to utilities. Easier HVAC maintenance. Better ventilation. Lower moisture issues. The list goes on.
When DO slabs make sense? Flood zones. Extremely rocky soil. High water tables. Budget is absolutely critical. But it's not 80% of builds.
The construction industry pushes slabs because they're faster. 3-5 days vs 7-10. But faster for WHO? Not the homeowner dealing with repairs.

thread_structure: 5 foundation red flags your inspector probably missed (but that'll cost you $50K+ down the road): 🧵
1) Hairline cracks at 45° angles from windows/doors. Everyone says "all foundations crack." True. But THESE cracks? Differential settlement. Get a structural engineer. Now.
2) Gaps between baseboard and floor exceeding 1/4". Your floor is moving away from the walls. Foundation is either settling or heaving. Not cosmetic.
3) Doors that stick in humid weather but close fine when dry. Moisture under slab. Expansive soil activating. Early warning sign most inspectors ignore.
4) Nail pops in drywall forming a pattern/line. Random nail pops? Normal settling. A LINE of them? Your foundation is moving directionally. Document with photos.
5) Gutters draining within 5 feet of foundation. Not technically a foundation issue YET. But it will be. Improper drainage is the #1 cause of foundation problems.
Bought a house in the last 5 years? Walk around and check these. Catch them early and you're looking at $2-8K in repairs. Wait 3 years? $50-150K.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: "You need to water your foundation in summer." Heard this advice? It's costing homeowners thousands. Here's what's actually happening: 🧵
thread_structure: "You need to water your foundation in summer." Heard this advice? It's costing homeowners thousands. Here's what's actually happening: 🧵
The logic seems sound: Dry soil shrinks. Shrinking soil pulls away from foundation. Foundation settles. So... add water! Right? Wrong.
What ACTUALLY happens: You water inconsistently. Soil expands. Foundation heaves. You stop watering. Soil contracts. Foundation settles. Repeat.
This cycle of expansion/contraction is WORSE than consistent dry conditions. You're literally creating the problem you're trying to prevent.
Real solution? Consistent moisture. Either: A) Don't water at all (foundation designed for local soil conditions), or B) Install soaker hoses on timers for CONSISTENT moisture year-round
But here's the thing: If your foundation needs watering to stay stable, it was poorly designed. Proper depth, proper reinforcement, proper soil prep = no watering needed.
I've repaired 200+ foundations. Know how many failed due to "not watering"? 3. Know how many failed due to inconsistent moisture from manual watering? 67.
Stop watering your foundation. If you have movement, call a structural engineer. The problem isn't moisture—it's design or drainage.
